Fourth, the capacities of those to whom the teachings are directed: The teachings are revealed through capacities, apart from capacities there are no teachings.
The above explains the vast and profound meaning and principles, but it is not yet clear what capacities they are directed towards.

If the able responder is the ten bodies and the perfect sound, now it directly shows what is directed, which generally has ten types. The first five distinguish those who are not suitable vessels, and the latter five show what is to be done.
Among the former, the first is those without faith who are not suitable vessels, because hearing it gives rise to slander and they fall into evil paths.
Second, those who violate the truth are not suitable vessels. Relying on this sutra to seek fame and profit, teaching the Dharma in an impure way, accumulating deviant goodness.
The sutra below says, Forgetting the bodhi mind and cultivating various roots of goodness is the work of Mara.
Third, those who deviate from reality are not suitable vessels. This refers to grasping the words literally and the ultimate truth that transcends the mind, because it does not enter the mind.
The treatise says, There are five faults in grasping the meaning according to the sound.
The above three are all ordinary fools, so the text below says, This sÅ«tra does not fall into the hands of other sentient beings.
Fourth, those of narrow and inferior capacity are not vessels, referring to all the two vehicles.
The chapter on appearance says, All the two vehicles do not hear this sÅ«tra, let alone uphold it.
Therefore, although they are present, they are like the deaf and the blind.

Fifth, those who uphold provisional [teachings] are not vessels, referring to the bodhisattvas of the common teaching of the three vehicles, who practice according to their own teachings and stages, and do not believe in the perfect and endowed Dharma.

The later sÅ«tra says, Suppose there are bodhisattvas who practice the six perfections for immeasurable koá¹­Ä«s of nayutas of kalpas, but do not hear this sÅ«tra, or even if they hear it, they do not believe, understand, follow, or enter into it. They cannot be called true bodhisattvas.
Among the latter five that are revealed as the objects, the first is the correct object, referring to those with the perfect capacity for the One Vehicle.
The Chapter on Appearance states, This sÅ«tra is not spoken for other sentient beings, which generally refers to the previous five;

Only for the bodhisattvas riding the inconceivable vehicle is it spoken, which is the primary audience, meaning that one practice is all practices, and the stages are perfectly integrated, which is the profound inconceivability. Moreover, one can thoroughly understand all teachings, which is the vast inconceivability. Therefore, the text says, It is not known by others' minds, only those practicing the universal wisdom can enter, and so forth.
Second, the indirect audience, meaning those who, although not yet enlightened, are able to have faith and plant the seeds.
Like the metaphor of eating diamonds in the Chapter on Appearance.

The celestial sons in hell suddenly transcend to the tenth ground, and the great ocean and the fire at the end of the eon cannot obstruct them. Because they have not yet entered enlightenment, they are called the indirect audience.
Third, the audience to be guided, referring to the bodhisattvas of the provisional teachings who do not accept the perfectly integrated Dharma.

Within the ten grounds, the provisional stages are revealed to be superior. Borrowing the names of the three vehicles' distinctions, they say that they are the same as our Dharma. Later, through perfuming and cultivation, they will come to believe and enter the perfect and harmonious. Because apart from this universal Dharma there is nowhere to return to, and because the ultimate fruition of provisional teachings is not real.
Fourth, the provisional for the sake of others refers to the two vehicles. It means that since they do not hear it, how could they accept and uphold it?
Therefore, bodhisattvas provisionally demonstrate being Å›rÄvakas, either in the Dharma assembly being deaf and blind, showing their lack of a share;
or demonstrating being on the path and being enlightened, knowing that they can turn their minds.
Fifth, the distant benefit refers to all ordinary beings, non-Buddhists, and icchantikas, who all have buddha-nature. Although they do not believe now, later they will certainly enter.

The Appearance of the Tathagata Chapter says: The great medicine king tree of the Tathagata's wisdom cannot benefit those in two places, namely those in the pit of non-action who have fallen into the two vehicles, and those sentient beings who have destroyed their roots of goodness and are not vessels, drowning in the water of great wrong views and craving. However, he has never abandoned them.
The first three non-vessels are drowning in wrong views, and the fourth non-vessel has fallen into a deep pit, so they are all excluded.
Now the fourth and fifth clarify that the Buddha never abandons them, so he shows them and guides them, perfuming them to form seeds.

Moreover, in that chapter, it is explained that even those who do not believe and slander also plant good roots, meaning that although slanderers fall into evil realms, because they hear it through their ears, they will eventually awaken.
It also says: The sun also benefits the born-blind.
Moreover, in the analogy of the ocean's hidden flow, it is explained that there is none who does not possess the Tathagata's wisdom.
Moreover, in the analogy of destroying dust and revealing sutra scrolls, if one removes false thoughts, one will see the Buddha's wisdom.

All of this clarifies that the naturally abiding nature is precisely what is to be done, let alone the perfect interfusion of the Dharma-nature and the mutual interpenetration of stimulus and response, where there is not a single dharma that is not to be embraced.

Fifth, regarding the shallow and profound essence of the teachings, the nature of the inexhaustible ocean of teachings is difficult to fathom. From shallow to deep, ten essences are briefly explained:

First, the essence of sound and language; second, the essence of names, phrases, and sentences; third, the essence of comprehensively taking the four dharmas (sound, meaning, names, and sentences); the above three are all the essence of what can be expounded;

Fourth, the essence of comprehensively including what is expounded; fifth, the essence of all dharmas manifesting meaning; sixth, the essence of comprehensively including objects in the mind; seventh, the essence of reconciling conditions and entering reality; eighth, the essence of the unobstructed interfusion of phenomena and principle; ninth, the essence of the unobstructed interpenetration of all phenomena; tenth, the essence of the clear manifestation of the ocean seal.
Among the ten, the first five are only essence, while the latter five are both essence and nature.
Moreover, the first four are common to the Hinayana, while the latter six are only Mahayana.
The first seven are common to the Three Vehicles, while the latter three are only the One Vehicle.
The first eight are about the same teaching, and the last two are only about the distinct teaching.
Among the first three, the four dharmas of sound, name, phrase, and text are commonly used in both the Great and Lesser Vehicles.
There are three different ways of accepting and rejecting.
The three of the Lesser Vehicle are as stated in the 126th chapter of the Abhidharma-mahÄvibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra: What is the essence of the Buddha's teachings?
One says:
It should be said that it is of the nature of speech.
That is to say, the Buddha's speech, singing, discussion, voice, speech path, speech activity, and speech expression, are called the Buddha's teachings.
Name, phrase, and text only reveal the function of the Buddha's teachings, not wishing to reveal the essence of the Buddha's teachings.

Name, etc. are the essence, that is to say, the body of names, the body of phrases, and the body of texts, because they are arranged in sequence, placed in order, and connected in sequence, therefore sound is only based on the indirect cause.
That is to say, speech gives rise to names, and names are able to manifest meaning.
The intention of the evaluators takes speech as its essence.
The *Samayabhedoparacanacakra* agrees with the *AbhidharmakoÅ›a*.

The *AbhidharmakoÅ›a* says, The Sage has said that the aggregates of teachings number eighty thousand. Their essence is either speech or names, and they are subsumed in the form and compositional factors aggregates.

That is to say, if speech is taken as the essence of the teachings, then they are subsumed in the form aggregate. If names are taken as the essence of the teachings, then they are subsumed in the compositional factors aggregate.
This is because both of the former two are preserved, and there is no preference, so the word or is used.

After explaining the third interpretation of the previous verse, it says, Because it manifests meaning as it is, it is called the Buddha's teachings.
Because names are able to manifest meaning, the teachings are names.
Therefore the Buddha's teachings definitely take names as their essence. Names are brought up as the foremost to subsume phrases and texts.
The third chapter of the *AbhidharmadÄ«pa* also explains it in the same way.
Third, the intention of the Abhidharma-koÅ›a is to have no attachment to either position. If one accepts both, then the four dharmas are combined as the essence of the teaching.

If the intention of the SautrÄntika is also to only take sound, then the NyÄyÄnusÄra-Å›Ästra, fascicle 14, refutes that teacher, saying You should not establish the aggregates of name, phrase, and syllable, which have sound as their essence.

Taking the provisional from the real, sound is taken as the essence. Apart from sound, there are no separate names, phrases, etc.
The fifth chapter of the Saá¹ƒdhinirmocana-sÅ«tra says The sounds of the TathÄgata are roughly of three kinds:
1. SÅ«tras, etc.

Second:
Following the function, names, etc. are taken as the essence, because they can express the intrinsic nature and distinctions of all dharmas and are the basis of both.
Therefore, the Abhidharma-samuccaya-vyÄkhyÄ refutes the SautrÄntika school, saying, It is unreasonable for the phrases and sentences of the scriptures to have language as their intrinsic nature.

The VijÃ±aptimÄtratÄ-siddhi also refutes them, saying, If names, phrases, and syllables are not different from sound, then the objects of the unimpeded eloquence of the Dharma and of words should not be different.

The VijÃ±aptimÄtratÄ-siddhi says, Although these three are separate from sound and do not have a separate substance, they are different in being provisional or real, and are also not the same as sound.
The third says:
The essence of the three is a combination of sound, names, phrases, and syllables, because the previous two explanations both have reasonable teachings as definitive standards.
The fourth chapter of the Saá¹ƒdhinirmocana-sÅ«tra says, One cannot proclaim without abandoning spoken words and written letters.
The VimalakÄ«rti-nirdeÅ›a-sÅ«tra says, There are those who use sounds, words, and written letters to perform the Buddha's work.
The DaÅ›abhÅ«mika-vibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra says, The speaker speaks using two things, and the listener hears using two things, namely, good sounds and good words.
According to my understanding, both should be accepted.
If one chooses between the first two, why rely on names, etc.?
The reason is that sound alone is precisely about the Buddha's teachings, and it may be the essence of the teachings;

The previous VimalakÄ«rti SÅ«tra and DaÅ›abhÅ«mika SÅ«tra both include four, but they only speak of what is used, not the essence.

However, although the various schools of the Great and Small Vehicles all use the four dharmas, their principles are different. The SarvÃ¢stivÄda school holds that the four dharmas all have real substance;

Fourth, as for the essence of the teachings that are comprehensively included, the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi-Å›Ästra, fascicle 81, says, The essence of the sÅ«tras is roughly of two kinds:
First, words; second, meaning.
Words are the basis, and meaning is what is based on.
These two are collectively called the realm of all knowable things.
It is based on the six words to reveal the ten meanings. This clarifies the mutual accomplishment of the teachings and meanings.
If it does not express meaning, what is the use of the written teachings?
Therefore, the essence of the sutra is formed by comprehensively taking what is expressed.
Moreover, the Ten Stages Sutra says: The words follow the meaning, and the meaning follows the words. When the words and meaning follow each other without contradiction, it is the true teaching.

Also, the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra says: The Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, etc. are the speakers. Language is the characteristic of speaking. The aggregates of names, phrases, and syllables are the characteristics of what is spoken.

The fifth interpretation is that the essence of the teachings is that all dharmas manifest meaning, meaning that they are all able to manifest the principles and meanings.

Moreover, in the Fragrant Accumulations world, one manifests samÄdhi by eating fragrant food. In the buddha-land of Ultimate Bliss, one attains right mindfulness by listening to the wind in the trees. Silk and bamboo can transmit the mind, and the eyes can be used to preserve the Way. How much more so for the ocean of the nature of the Huayan, where cloud platforms and jeweled nets all emit wonderful sounds, pores and light are all able to expound the Dharma, and clouds and trees of flowers and incense are the Dharma gates of the Dharma realm, and lands and beings are the fundamental true body of the ten abodes. What is not the teaching?
Below it says: Lands speak, sentient beings speak, and everything in the three times speaks.
It also says: All realms in the world are able to turn the wheel of the Dharma. And so on.
There are many such passages.
Sixth, as for subsuming objects within mind, the essence is that the previous five are not apart from consciousness.
The Mere Consciousness and other texts say:
All that exists is only the manifestation of mind.
The Awakening of Faith also says: Based on the Dharma of one mind, there are two kinds of gates:
The gate of the suchness of mind and the gate of the arising and ceasing of mind.
However, these two gates each comprehensively include all dharmas, because these two gates are inseparable.
The chapter on pure conduct says, Knowing that all dharmas are the mind's own nature, they are only manifested by the mind.
However, there are two approaches:
The first is the mutual correspondence between the original and its reflection, and the second is the complete inclusion of the expounder and listener.
Among the former, the four statements are established based on all teachings:
The first is only the original and no reflection, referring to the Lesser Vehicle, because they do not know about consciousness only.

The second is both the original and the reflection, referring to the initial teaching of the Great Vehicle, which states that the Buddha's own proclamation of the text and its meaning are all manifested by the pure consciousness associated with the TathÄgata's wondrous observation wisdom, which is called the substantial teaching.

The Buddha Land Treatise, fascicle one, says, There is an interpretation that by the power of the superior conditions of the good fundamental vows of the listener, the aspects of text and meaning arise in the TathÄgata's consciousness.
These aspects of text and meaning arise from the Buddha's beneficial roots for benefiting others, and are called the Buddha's teachings;
The text and meaning that transform and appear in the consciousness of the listener are called reflections.
The MahÄyÄna-abhidharma-samuccaya-vyÄkhyÄ says: By the power of the TathÄgata's original vow of compassion, the images of words and meanings arise in the consciousness of the listener.
Although these images of words and meanings arise directly from the power of one's own wholesome roots, they are called the Buddha's teaching based on the dominant condition.
The VimsatikÄ VijÃ±aptimÄtratÄ-siddhi says: By the power of mutual dominance, the two consciousnesses become definite.

The masters such as DharmapÄla all establish this meaning, but they say that the images of words and meanings arise, and further explain the five minds that gather and appear, which means that when it is said that all conditioned things are impermanent, there are four sounds, four characters, four names, one sentence, and the meaning expressed.
These fourteen images gather and appear in the consciousness of the listener.
However, there are many Western explanations, and now I will briefly present one of them.
It means that when the character all is spoken, there are two minds of chance and seeking, but it is not yet known to which the character all belongs, so there is no mind of determination.

Next, the syllable xing is spoken. Due to prior habituation, the understanding arises in sequence. There are three mental states: spontaneous, seeking, and determining. This is because the xing is determined to belong to all the syllables.
Hearing the syllable xing, although one knows its nature, one still does not know its meaning;

In order to make one know the meaning, the syllable wu is spoken again. There are only two mental states: spontaneous and seeking. There is no determining yet, because the wu has not yet been determined to belong to anything.

Later, the syllable chang is spoken. Due to the power of the previous syllables, they are gradually habituated and the subsequent syllables arise in sequence. There are five mental states: spontaneous, seeking, determining, defiled and pure, and flowing equally.

At the very last moment, when the four syllables are complete, one is then able to understand the meaning. There are twelve mental states in total: the first two, the next three, the next two, and the last five. Therefore, there are fourteen characteristics. The meaning is as explained above.
The rest is as explained in other chapters.
Third, there is only the reflection without the original, which refers to the true teaching of the Great Vehicle.
Apart from the minds of sentient beings, the fruition of Buddhahood has no form, sound, or meritorious qualities. Only thusness and the wisdom of thusness remain alone.

Great compassion and great wisdom serve as the dominant conditions, enabling the Buddhas to manifest their form and sound in the minds of sentient beings who are ready to be transformed and to expound the Dharma. Therefore, the holy teachings are only the reflections in the minds of sentient beings.
A verse from the Heaven of YÄma says: The Buddhas have no Dharma, so how can they have any teachings?
They only follow their own minds and say that such a Dharma exists.
The masters such as NÄgÃ¢rjuna and Sthiramati all establish this meaning.
Fourth, neither original nor reflected, as taught in the sudden teachings.
Not only is there no Buddha's form and sound outside the mind, even the reflections within the minds of sentient beings are empty, because their nature is originally free.
Beyond words and thoughts, it is the teaching that is not a teaching.
A verse from the Mount Sumeru says: The nature of dharmas is originally empty and tranquil, without grasping and also without seeing.
The emptiness of nature is precisely the Buddha, which cannot be conceived or measured.
The VimalakÄ«rti-nirdeÅ›a SÅ«tra says, The one who expounds the Dharma has no speaking and no demonstration, and the one who listens to the Dharma has no hearing and no attainment.
The school of NÄgÄrjuna and others often establishes this meaning.
These first four explanations are combined into one perfect and unobstructed whole, in order to guide sentient beings from the shallow to the profound.
The second explanation completely includes both the expounder and the listener, forming two sets of four statements:

First, using the common teaching to form four statements. This means that outside of the true mind of the Buddha there are no separate sentient beings, because the true mind of sentient beings is precisely the true mind of the Buddha.
Then there is only speaking and no listening, so the taught teachings are only manifested by the Buddha.
Second, outside of the minds of sentient beings there is no separate Buddha, because the true mind of the Buddha is precisely the true mind of sentient beings.
Then there is only listening and no speaking, so the taught teachings are precisely manifested by sentient beings themselves.
The Brahma's Net Sutra says, Know that all dharmas are the self-nature of the mind and so forth.

When the true mind of the Buddha appears, it does not obstruct the appearance of the true mind of sentient beings, therefore it is said that both the speaker and listener exist, and the two teachings are established equally.

Fourth, because the Buddha is precisely sentient beings, he is not the Buddha; because sentient beings are precisely the Buddha, they are not sentient beings. Mutually negating and both disappearing, then the speaker and listener are quiescent.

Therefore the VimalakÄ«rti-nirdeÅ›a-sÅ«tra says, For the one who expounds the Dharma, there is no speaking and no demonstration; for the one who listens to the Dharma, there is no hearing and no attainment.

Second, using the separate teaching to clarify the four statements, it means that because the characteristics are not destroyed, the Buddha and sentient beings mutually exist, and because one sentient being completely exists within the Buddha, then the fruition aspect encompasses all phenomena without exception.
Sentient beings still exist within the Buddha's mind, let alone the teachings spoken not only being manifested by the Buddha?

Therefore the chapter on manifestation says, When the TathÄgata attains perfect enlightenment, he universally sees all sentient beings attaining perfect enlightenment within his body, up to universally seeing all sentient beings entering nirvÄá¹‡a.

The second chapter of the Buddha-Nature Treatise, The Chapter on the TathÄgatagarbha, says: All sentient beings are completely within the wisdom of the TathÄgata, and are therefore called the womb, because the wisdom of suchness accords with the realm of suchness.
All sentient beings definitely have never left the realm of suchness, and are all embraced by the TathÄgata, and are therefore called the womb, and sentient beings are the womb of the TathÄgata.

It is also clarified in the chapter on manifestation below that the thoughts, faculties, and desires of all sentient beings in the kalpas and lands of the three times are all suddenly manifested in one body, let alone the vast wisdom of the Buddha being like empty space?
Second, because the Buddha is in the minds of sentient beings, the approach of causes includes all dharmas without exception.
Since the Buddha is already in the mind, let alone the teachings spoken not being manifested in the minds of sentient beings?
Therefore, the chapter on manifestation says: Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should know that in their own minds, moment after moment, there are Buddhas attaining perfect enlightenment.
Why is it so?
Because all buddhas and tathÄgatas do not depart from this mind to achieve perfect enlightenment.
Just as in one's own mind, the minds of all sentient beings are also like this, all having buddhas achieving perfect enlightenment.

This clarifies that the buddhas' realization of enlightenment in the true suchness of sentient beings' minds is the same as original enlightenment, and that the fundamental and the beginning are the same. In total, it is in the minds of sentient beings, arising from the essence and giving rise to function.
When manifesting the responsive and transformation bodies, it is precisely the great function of true suchness in the minds of sentient beings. There is no other buddha.
As explained in the Awakening of Faith, this meaning is often clarified, but it is the essence and function of one's own mind.
Now, using this sÅ«tra, because the mind, buddha, and sentient beings are without distinction, the buddhas realize the essence of sentient beings and use the function of sentient beings.

Third, due to the mutual presence of buddhas and sentient beings in the past, each is real and not false. Then cause and effect penetrate each other, and each sacred teaching is entirely in the two minds. Therefore, the buddhas in the minds of sentient beings expound the Dharma for the sentient beings in the minds of the buddhas;
In the mind of the Buddha, sentient beings listen to the Buddha speaking the Dharma in the mind of sentient beings.
Fourth, since the arising is entirely in the Buddha, it is the same as the Buddha, which is not arising;
The Buddha is entirely in arising, which is the same as arising, which is not the Buddha.

The two mutually negate each other, and the two states are equally merged. In accordance with a single holy teaching, both minds are not. Then, in the mind of the Buddha, sentient beings have no listening, and in the mind of sentient beings, the Buddha has no speaking.
Therefore, the Chapter on the Foremost of Worthies says, What is produced by causes and conditions has no arising. The Dharma body of the buddhas is not a body.
Also, the Chapter on Praising in Verse says, The TathÄgata does not speak the Dharma, nor does he liberate sentient beings.
The Great Perfection of Wisdom Sutra, fascicle 425, says, Since I attained the Way, I have not spoken a single word, and you have not heard it either.
Therefore, these four are perfectly integrated and unobstructed in a single holy teaching, which is the ultimate principle of consciousness only.
The seventh is the essence of the convergence of conditions entering into reality, because the previous six gates all enter into one reality.
This also has two meanings:
First, subsuming the branches by returning to the root; second, revealing the nature by unifying phenomena.

Among the former, all the holy teachings flow from the true, and therefore are no different from the true. Therefore, the MahÄyÄnasaá¹ƒgraha calls them the twelve divisions of the canon that flow from suchness.

The tenth chapter of the VijÃ±aptimÄtratÄ-siddhi-Å›Ästra explains the suchness of the supreme flow: It is said that the teachings that flow from this suchness are the most supreme among all other teachings.

Although the school does not establish suchness as following conditions, it says that the Buddha's fundamental wisdom realizes the purest dharma realm, and then establishes the teachings as being called the flow of suchness. Subsuming the branches by returning to the root is also called using suchness as the essence of the teachings.
Second, revealing the nature by unifying phenomena means that all the differentiated teachings have no nature of their own from conditions, and are therefore suchness.
Therefore, false characteristics are originally exhausted, and true nature is originally manifested. The words of the TathÄgata all accord with reality.
Therefore, the Vajra SamÄdhi SÅ«tra says: As for what I say, it is meaningful speech, not mere words.
As for what sentient beings say, it is verbal speech, not meaningful.
The Benevolent Kings' SÅ«tra, chapter on the two truths, says: Great King!
The Dharma wheel is the Dharma as it is, the verses as they are, up to the discussions as they are, and so forth.
This sÅ«tra clarifies that the teachings are identical to reality, not that all that is like reality is the teachings.
If one takes all dharmas that reveal the meaning to be the essence of the teachings, then all dharmas are like reality, and there is no reality that is not the teachings.

The eighth aspect, the essence of the unobstructed interfusion of principle and phenomena, refers to the fact that although all the teachings as a whole are identical to reality, this does not obstruct the twelve divisions of the canon and other phenomena from clearly manifesting.
Although reality as a whole is all things, this does not obstruct its single flavor of tranquil and uniform equality.
Just as space is unobstructed, the Buddha's voice also accords with unobstructed space, because it is all in accord with the wisdom of suchness.
As extensively explained in the section on the scope of meaning above.
The ninth, the essence of the unobstructed interpenetration of all phenomena, is that both the words and meanings are perfect. The words are the perfect sound.
This also includes the ten profound gates.
The Appearance of the Chapter says: The Buddha emits one wonderful sound, which is heard throughout the ten directions, and all sounds are complete, with the rain of Dharma filling everywhere.
This is the essence of the simultaneous perfect correspondence.

The Chapter on the Ten Abodes says: Wishing to fully expound a single phrase of the Dharma, for incalculably long eons it is inexhaustible, yet causing the words and meanings to be different from each other, the bodhisattva gives rise to the initial resolve with this.
This is the essence of the unobstructed interpenetration of the vast and the minute, also called the teaching of purity and impurity.
A single phrase is indestructible, minute, and pure.
The words and meanings are different, vast, and mixed.
It also says understanding many in one dharma, understanding one in many dharmas, and so on, which are all teachings of mutual containment of one and many.
The Appearance of the Tathagata chapter says the Tathagata's voice universally enters everything, like writing characters, and so on, which is also mutual containment through mutual penetration.
The Ten Abodes also says one is many, many is one, the text follows the meaning, the meaning follows the text, which is the essence of the teaching of mutual identity.

The Appearance of the Tathagata chapter says all at the site of enlightenment hear it, without leaving the assembly, each according to their understanding, which is the essence of the teaching of concealment and revelation.

It also says the Tathagata's speech is only of one flavor, but due to the differences in the mental capacities of sentient beings, there are innumerable distinctions, which is also the essence of the teaching of concealment and revelation, as well as the teaching of purity and impurity.
